title: The Rhythm of Light
subtitle: Puglia's climate is less about seasons and more about rhythm—the pulse of light, heat, and the sea.

modes.label: Salento (Lecce, Gallipoli)
modes.description: The southernmost tip—warmest, driest, longest swimming season.
modes.notes: Summer heat is intense but dry. Sea swimmable April-October. Minimal rain. Sirocco winds from Africa bring occasional heat spikes.

modes.label: Bari Coast (Polignano, Monopoli)
modes.description: Adriatic breeze moderates heat; slightly cooler than Salento.
modes.notes: Coastal breezes make summer more bearable. Rain slightly more frequent in fall/winter. Sea swimmable May-October.

modes.label: Gargano (Vieste, Mattinata)
modes.description: Northern peninsula—greener, slightly cooler, more variable weather.
modes.notes: More rainfall than southern Puglia, especially in winter. Forested interior creates microclimates. Cooler nights even in summer.

modes.label: Valle d'Itria (Ostuni, Locorotondo)
modes.description: Inland hill country—trulli towns with slightly cooler temps and fresh air.
modes.notes: Elevated position (200-400m) provides relief from coastal heat. Cooler nights year-round. More rain than coast but still dry by northern Italy standards.

seasonalNotes.winter: Quiet coastlines, pruning olive trees, empty beaches. Mild temps but occasional rain. Fireplace season. Perfect for exploring without crowds.
seasonalNotes.spring: Wildflowers explode across Valle d'Itria. Festival season begins. Swimming starts by late April. Light, golden mornings. The best time to arrive.
seasonalNotes.summer: Heat. Festas. Sea life. Siestas mandatory. Beaches at full capacity. Temperatures regularly hit 35-40°C. Air conditioning essential. Social life moves outdoors entirely—dinner at 10pm, aperitivo at sunset, swimming at dawn.
seasonalNotes.autumn: Grape harvest in Manduria, olive picking across the region. Seas still warm through October. Crowds thin, prices drop. Second spring—arguably the best season.
